subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etyl|爲}}
{{Han simp|爲}}.

In the oracle bone script, it is an {{Han compound|又|t1=hand|象|t2=elephant|ls=ic|nocap=1}} — a hand holding an elephant. The {{zh-l|*又}} later became {{zh-l|*爪|hand; claw}}.

''{{w|Shuowen Jiezi}}'' interprets the character as a representation of the female macaque.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
The two pronunciations below (“to make; to do; to be”, “for; to; because”) are cognate; the latter is the *''–s'' derivative of the former. Words meaning “to make, to do” often have secondary meanings of “for, as” – compare {{zh-m|*作}}.

Etymology not certain. {{zh-ref|Starostin}} compared this word with {{cog|bo|བགྱིད||to make, to manufacture}}, {{m|bo|བགྱི་བ||action, deed}}, {{m|bo|ཡིན||is, be}} and {{cog|my|ဝေ||to distribute, to share}}. {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} listed {{m|mkh-pro|*ʔaajh||to give}} (> {{cog|km|ឲ្យ||to give, to donate}}) and {{cog|km|ធ្វើ||to do, to make}}, although the vowels do not match.

The graphic representation using a monkey or an elephant probably stems from a homophonic or near-homophonic etymon which was rarely attested; compare {{cog|sit-pro|*b/g-woj-n}} > {{cog|kac|woi||monkey}} and possibly {{och-l|猿|ape}}. STEDT considers this word to be a possible descendant of {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*m-gwi(j)||elephant}}. Outside Sino-Tibetan, compare {{cog|mkh-vie-pro|*-vɔːj||elephant}} > {{cog|vi|voi||elephant}}.
